> > > Now, If I tried to write a white-box test on my component, I run
> > into
> > > some serious setbacks.  That white-box (or micro test) is tied to
> > the
> > > component implementation.  I cannot reuse that test on another
> > > implementation of the same component interface.  That is a serious
> > > drawback to me.
> >
> > A very serious drawback of not adjusting tests to implementation
> > details is that sufficient tests for one implementation are most
> > probably insufficient for another. That doesn't mean that you can't
> > reuse them - it's just that it isn't safe relying on them.
>
> True.  However I do not throw away tests--I add them.  As we find more
> ways of breaking the component, we add that test to the component's
> testcase.  That introduces regression testing--and ensures that all
> implementations of a component don't break when a new regression is
> added.
>
> Two truths:
>
> * You can't know all the design from the beginning.
> * You can't know all the tests from the beginning.
>
> It is an iterative process.  As things fail, you add a regression
test,
> then you fix the problem.  The order is important--write the test
before
> you fix the problem.

But why do you wait for a bug report to add tests, if you can find out
about the interesting boundary conditions of the new implementation by
just looking at the code???

Still curious, Ilja
